You're asking by whom was Apartheid considered a worse alternative than sabotage resulting in some civilian casualties. Well for starters, by the millions of black South Africans denied the vote and the dignity of full citizenship in their country. And who, if they protested and demanded equal rights, were shot, detained without trial, tortured to death. Does it need to be debated that Apartheid was very very bad? Black South Africans were legally deemed "third class citizens", after Coloured and Indian South Africans, who were "second class". This was written into law, and displayed on railway platforms, in case anyone forgot that whites were "first class". How could a man live under such laws and find them acceptable? It must be considered wrong, as Naziism is considered wrong, as slavery and genocide and communism are considered wrong. It seems astonishing to me that you would question who would find Apartheid unacceptable. I mean, are you entertaining the position that it was only unacceptable for blacks, but the whites were fine? You know that this isn't the first time this sort of thing has come up, yes? We've seen various "modern eras" even in the Saxon world which end with a King coming to power simply because the people hate their "representatives" in Parliament, and visa versa. 

In fact, the only reason Parliament was able to usurp King James II and install William was due to their victory in the English Civil WAR in the decades prior, despite the previously "wholly ingrained" notion that the King was the one with the rightful power to rule. 

Then lets go back further, the Norman invasions, when William the Great established himself as Supreme Monarch despite the "wholly ingrained" notion that the Saxon elective was the only legitimate way to determine whom ought to wear the Crown.

The point is this: no matter how "obvious" one way of governance may seem to us in this moment, that can and will change with the right pressures.  Given Parliament has utterly destroyed England in the past 30 years, given Charles is a useless lout yet Heir Apparent William is a very well liked and Charismatic leader, there exists a very real possibility we'll see a massive shift in perspective on the matter. text:
So, the sacred cows have been taken down in this podcast.

MLK was an American preacher with numerous affairs and communist leanings. Well, just another Tuesday.

Gandhi, for all his veneration, was a deeply self-interested man willing to see millions of his countrymen sent to slaughter in pursuit of publicity and symbolic victories‚Äîan approach that, to be fair, was highly effective in shaping his legacy. Even more ironic is that he did not extend his commitment to nonviolence to his own wife. More importantly, he helped establish a government that was not only corrupt and deeply retaliatory but also obsessed with maintaining a performative image rather than ensuring functional governance.

Nelson Mandela, despite his later reputation, was linked to numerous bombings and the practice of necklacing‚Äîa brutal execution method where tires were placed around the necks of political enemies, particularly those targeted by his wife, Winnie Mandela, before being set on fire. After his rise to power, much like Gandhi, he oversaw a government that was both corrupt and deeply retaliatory, but more significantly, one that prioritized optics over actual governance.

After years of potshots at traditional conservative cultural heroes, it‚Äôs refreshing to see the right going after the left‚Äôs icons‚Äîparticularly those with feet of clay.

replies.author: @andrewshaw1571
replies.text:
@destinypirate Right, a few things to go over. Firstly, discussing the british in india is largely too simple. There were many different interest groups, all of which had a different vision when they interfered in india yet all of which, due to the shared need for not getting booted, would lock arms when under threat.

So theres the true believers that genuinely thought they were improving india by westernising it, those who thought india was better improved by keeping its own culture but modernising technologically, those who sought to keep india reliant on britain, those simply in it not for any geopolitical goal but simply to make private money and others.

If local indians kicked off, all of the above would huddle together with a united front since as much as they were all mutually exclusive, they all shared the baseline need of not getting killed.

So talking about 'the british' in india, really needs fleshing out since 'british' interests werent a monolith.

Secondly, britain official policy in terms of india, it was dominion status which is ultimately, effective independence. It took a long time since britain didnt think india was capable of forming a cohesive state for much of the 1900's but that was the ultimate goal, where independance, like with the other dominions, wouldnt be a problem since under the umbrella or walking separate, the former dominions would, through shared history and institutions, be natural friends. Things didnt work out that way, due to britain having to rush indian dominion status post war. For the record, the concern of the nation being unable to form was proved largely correct given the raj didnt form a country, it had to form 4.

So violence or gandhi, india didnt take its independence from britain, it was given it and the financial strain of the war probably played the largest part in the rushed nature as otherwise, it was a delaying factor in britains already agreed upon plans.

None of this mind, is to imply that britain in india is justified, whatever plans you intend with occupied land, its still not yours to make plans with be they benevolent or evil.

The final point is a simple contradiction of a claim you made. "England has become demonstrably worse than it was before. Indian people, with the means to do so used to move to the uk, not so anymore"

Yes so thus far actually. Indian immigration to the UK since 2011 has been the highest rate ever, beating even post independence. nearly 250,000 came between june 2023 and june 2024, half for work, half for study. Thats the latest figures.

So yes, indians are still coming to the uk, in higher numbers than ever.

replies.author: @destinypirate
replies.text:
@andrewshaw1571¬† I think that it's great that you took the time to write this, but most of it does not apply...
- it was never England's right to decide how to or who should rule, or when, or why. All of these decisions were upheld at the end of cannons and guns and bayonets primarily manned Scots and Irish and even Indians. 
We could take the time to argue the merits of forced benevolence. However there isn't a people on the Earth who wouldn't rather kill or die in order to retain their sovereignty against such Force. Any other man, as exemplified through the totality of History, any other man who became the leader against such an occupying and exploitative force would have gathered the people with serpent knives and pitchforks. Gandhi is unique in history and his philosophical approach. The eloquence of his peaceful Revolution save the lives of countless thousands of British subjects, and quite likely those of other other foreign Nationals who held interest there, and countless thousands more if not millions of indians.

What would be an interesting topic is examining how Indians took the influence, which was forced upon them, of British education and modernization and used it to improve themselves and their country so impressively. Many questions could be explored including whether they would have achieved such progress without suffering British conquest.
We'd of course have to do a bit of comparative study of other countries, a difficult task give me the different cultural and Geographic factors, yet China does come to mind where we see the pointed infusion of Western culture through Hong Kong.

Clearly my suggestion about immigration changes was too anecdotal as among the many Indian International people I know none are interested in moving to the UK anymore and and rather choose to stay in India or satellite out to the US or even varied countries such as Thailand, Singapore, or Canada.

As reported from everyone of my UK friends who lived through quite a varied strata of the country, conditions in the UK are deteriorating Atari moving from bad to worse, which is quite the opposite of the  reports that I hear from India.

I see no rational reason for this diminishing of Gandhi Nora of this softening of the British Empires history. Undoubtedly there were Great gains in modernization and trade and education to be had for Any Nation engaged with the British or Americans. However this may be it does not change the brutality and suffering and loss of Conquest and occupation, nor the immorality. There's certainly where Alternatives and Thailand May exemplify this better than any other nation, having benefited from their own Royal leadership that acted with the wisdom to not only make treaties and alliances but also to invite in Western expertise and be open to business lia's which built up the countrys  infrastructure. Of course this progress has waned since the passing away of such wise leadership...

Much more is to be gained from studying the wise leadership of the Great Men of the 20th century than is from tearing them down for whatever personal shortcomings or varied factors can be woven over them.
Many of these great men were British as well and examination of the beneficent intense and wisdom of such is more worthwhile than simply vilifying Britain for the wrongs that are clearly understood to be wrong already. However in doing so we can't throw out the courage and wisdom of those who did resist the oppressive Brits.

 The most impactful example of the dangers of search loaded historical revisionism is the impact on American academia wrought by the naive embrace of A People's History of the United States.

replies.text: I agree that Nelson was a hero for his actions and leadership at Cape St Vincent, Aboukir Bay, Copenhagen and Trafalgar and that he is probably the greatest military leader we‚Äôve ever had. However, he also was far from perfect, his affair with Emma Hamilton was an absolute embarrassment, his fellow admirals likened him to a dog led about on a leash by her. His entire year spent at the royal court in Naples was shameful and very nearly destroyed his career. His private letters also reveal he vehemently opposed Wilberforce and the abolitionist movement. Still one of the greatest Britons in our history but important to remember that none of these men were perfect.

replies.author: @sailormatlac9114
replies.text: @Cronus1312 Never meet your heroes they say... Honestly, nobody is perfect. A good example is Canada's first PM, Alexander MacDonald. They guy was universally despised by his compatriots, a drunkard and a morally bankrupt man, but he also was the only one with the energy and decision to make a functioning country out of a patchwork of bickering colonies. It's for that single reason he got statues and places named in his honor. Nobody ever thought he was a role model to follow, but most sane people new that he raised to the challenge when he had too. I can accept seeing his face here and there. And can understand the general truth that most humans make some contribution to society, in some shape or form.

author: @maxnovax3948
text: My father was a cop in New Delhi in the 1940s.  He was in charge of crowd control at a Ghandi speech.  He closed the park gates at one point to prevent crushing injuries as people pushed to get in.  Ghandi stormed off the stage and confronted my Dad;  gave him orders to "Let my people in!", which were rebuffed.  Then he threatened to take away Dad's job.  The answer he got was:  That will be tomorrow.  Today I'm in charge of keeping your followers safe;  this square is closed off to more people and it's staying that way.  These folks can watch from outside the fence.  Now;  I'm busy doing my job.  You go back to that stage and do yours.   My Father kept his job in the end.

replies.author: @GabeSweetMan
replies.text:
Another thought has occurred to me: I find it interesting that we Americans even bother to sanitize our cultural heroes. Personally, I think it adds to the human experience to learn and come to terms with the less admirable qualities of our forefathers. Benjamin Franklin was also an adulterer (what with his questionable taste for French women) but he's on our $100 dollar bill for a reason. Similarly, we literally put Lincoln on a THRONE despite being one of the singularly most tyrannical leaders in our nation's history (he freed the slaves, but did so in the bloodiest way possible and stripped people of their God given rights and freedom of speech, which is ANTITHETICAL to America's founding principles).

I think it would be healthier for society if we taught our children both the virtues AND vices of our national heroes and their legacies because it sends a far more powerful message to our young people: You do not need to be a flawless paragon of virtue to be a hero.

You can condemn their failures while still upholding the good they brought to the world.
